page.title: List of state visits made by King Olav V of Norway

revision.text:
Below is a complete '''list of [[state visit]]s made by King [[Olav V of Norway]]''' during his reign from 1957 to 1991. A state visit is a formal visit by one [[head of state]] to another country, at the invitation of the other country's head of state. State visits are the highest form of diplomatic contact between two states, and are marked by major ceremonial and diplomatic formality. As such this list might give an indication to the foreign relations of Norway during this period.
==1950s== * 11–13 September 1958: [[Kingdom of Denmark]], visiting King [[Frederick IX of Denmark|Frederick IX]] and Queen [[Ingrid of Sweden|Ingrid]] * 23–25 April 1959: [[Kingdom of Sweden]], visiting King [[Gustaf VI Adolf of Sweden|Gustaf VI Adolf]] and Queen [[Louise Mountbatten|Louise]]
==1960s== * 31 May -2 June 1961: [[Republic of Iceland]], visiting President [[Ásgeir Ásgeirsson]] * 5–7 July 1961: [[Republic of Finland]], visiting President [[Urho Kekkonen]] * 26–28 September 1962: [[Republic of France]], visiting President [[Charles de Gaulle]] * 16–18 October 1962: [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]], visiting Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and [[Prince Philip]]. This state visit was made to [[Scotland]] in order to express gratitude for the Scottish people's help during [[World War II]].<ref>[http://www.aftenposten.no/fakta/olav/article451288.ece Afteposten article on the relationship between King Olav and the UK] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031224847/http://www.aftenposten.no/fakta/olav/article451288.ece |date=2007-10-31 }} (Norwegian)</ref> * 9–11 September 1964: [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]], visiting Queen [[Juliana of the Netherlands|Juliana]] and Prince [[Bernhard of Lippe-Biesterfeld|Bernhard]] * 14–15 September 1964: [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]], visiting Grand Duchess [[Charlotte, Grand Duchess of Luxembourg|Charlotte]] and Prince [[Felix of Bourbon-Parma|Felix]] * 21–23 September 1964: [[Kingdom of Belgium]], visiting King [[Baudouin I of Belgium|Baudouin I]] and Queen [[Queen Fabiola of Belgium|Fabiola]] * 7–14 January 1965: [[Iran|Empire of Iran]], visiting Shah [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] and Empress [[Farah Pahlavi]] * 15–23 January 1965: [[Kingdom of Thailand]], visiting King [[Bhumibol Adulyadej]] and Queen [[Sirikit]] * 10–17 January 1966: [[Empire of Ethiopia]], visiting Emperor [[Haile Selassie I of Ethiopia|Haile Selassie I]] * 5–9 September 1966: [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia]], visiting President [[Josip Broz Tito]] * 12–16 September 1966: [[Republic of Austria]], visiting President [[Franz Jonas]] * 26–28 April 1967: [[Italian Republic]], visiting President [[Giuseppe Saragat]] * 6–12 September 1967: [[Federative Republic of Brazil]], visiting President [[Artur da Costa e Silva]] * 13–16 September 1967: [[Republic of Chile]], visiting President [[Eduardo Frei Montalva]] * 18–21 September 1967: [[Argentine Republic]], visiting President [[Juan Carlos Onganía]] * 1–3 April 1968: [[Swiss Confederation]], visiting President [[Willy Spühler]] * 24 April - 1 May 1968: [[United States|United States of America]], visiting President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] * 5–11 May 1969: [[Tunisian Republic]], visiting President [[Habib Bourguiba]]
==1970s== *4–8 June 1973: [[Federal Republic of Germany]], visiting President [[Gustav Heinemann]] *4–6 June 1974: [[Republic of Iceland]], visiting President [[Kristján Eldjárn]] *11–13 September 1974: [[Kingdom of Denmark]], visiting Queen [[Margrethe II of Denmark|Margrethe II]] and Prince [[Henrik, Prince Consort of Denmark|Henrik]] *4–30 October 1975: [[United States|United States of America]], visiting President [[Gerald Ford]] *25–27 November 1975: [[Kingdom of Sweden]], visiting King [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf]] and Queen [[Queen Silvia of Sweden|Silvia]] *21–24 February 1978: [[Portuguese Republic]], visiting President [[António dos Santos Ramalho Eanes]]
==1980s== *7–10 October 1980: [[Republic of Finland]], visiting President [[Urho Kekkonen]] *13–15 September 1982: [[Republic of Austria]], visiting President [[Rudolf Kirchschläger]] *17–24 October 1983: [[Japan]], visiting Emperor [[Hirohito of Japan|Hirohito]] and Empress [[Empress Kōjun|Kōjun]] *29–31 March 1984: [[Kingdom of Spain]], visiting King [[Juan Carlos of Spain|Juan Carlos]] and Queen Sofia *23 November 1987: [[Canada]], visiting Governor General [[Jeanne Sauvé]] *12–15 April 1988: [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]], visiting Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and [[Prince Philip]]
==State visits hosted by King Olav== *1960 **11–13 February: [[Denmark]] **16–18 March: [[Sweden]] **19–21 September: [[Thailand]] *1961 **8–10 March: [[Finland]] **18–20 May: [[Iran]] *1963 **17–19 June: [[Tunisia]] **6–8 September: [[Tanganyika]] *1964 **1–3 June: [[Austria]] *1965 **10–12 May: [[Yugoslavia]] **14–16 June: [[Belgium]] **22–24 June: [[Italy]] *1970 **9–11 September: [[West Germany]] *1971 **3–5 May: [[Iceland]] *1973 **12–14 February: [[Denmark]] *1974 **8–10 October: [[Sweden]] *1976 **28–30 April: [[Tanzania]] *1978 **17–20 April: [[Austria]] *1980 **3–5 June: [[Portugal]] **13–15 November: [[Romania]] *1981 **5–8 May: [[Great Britain]] **26–27 May: [[Canada]] **21–23 October: [[Iceland]] *1982 **14–16 April: [[Spain]] *1983 **8–9 March: [[Finland]] *1984 **14–15 May: [[France]] *1985 **14–15 February: [[Zambia]] **10–11 June: [[Japan]] *1986 **13–15 May: [[Netherlands]] **24–26 September: [[West Germany]] *1990 **2–4 May: [[Luxembourg]]

{{Infobox Latter Day Saint biography | name = Lyman E. Johnson | PD_image = Lyman E. Johnson.JPG | birth_name = Lyman Eugene Johnson | birth_date = {{Birth date|1811|10|24}} | birth_place = [[Pomfret, Vermont|Pomfret]], [[Vermont]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1859|12|20|1811|10|24}} | death_place = [[Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin|Prairie du Chien]], [[Wisconsin]] | portals = Movement | position_or_quorum1 = [[Quorum of the Twelve#Members of the Quorum, prior to 1844|Quorum of the Twelve Apostles]] | president1 = [[Three Witnesses]] | start_date1 = {{start date|1835|02|14}} | end_date1 = {{end date|1837|09|03}}Johnson was disfellowshipped and removed from the Quorum of the Twelve on September 3, 1837. However, Johnson remained an apostle until his excommunication. | end_reason1 = Excommunicated for apostasy | position_or_quorum2 = [[Latter Day Saint]] [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|Apostle]] | president2 = [[Three Witnesses]] | start_date2 = {{start date|1835|02|14}} | ordination_reason2 = Initial organization of Quorum of the Twelve | end_date2 = {{end date|1838|04|13}} | end_reason2 = Excommunicated for apostasy | reorganization2 = No apostles immediately ordainedThe Quorum of the Twelve Apostles did not have twelve apostles again until April 8, 1841, when [[Lyman Wight]] was ordained. Between Johnson's excommunication and then, [[John E. Page]], [[John Taylor (Mormon)|John Taylor]], [[Wilford Woodruff]], [[George A. Smith]], and [[Willard Richards]] had been ordained and added to the Quorum to replace apostles who had been excommunicated or killed. | list_notes = Excommunicated in 1838 for apostasy. }} '''Lyman Eugene Johnson''' (October 24, 1811 – December 20, 1859)Prairie du Chien Courier 8 (December 20, 1859):3 and headstone of Lyman E. Johnson in Evergreen Cemetery, Prairie du Chien, Wisconsin. was an early leader in the [[Latter Day Saint movement]] and an original member of the [[Quorum of the Twelve|Quorum of the Twelve Apostles]]. He broke with [[Joseph Smith]] and [[Sidney Rigdon]] during the 1837–38 period when [[schism]] divided the early church. Johnson later became a successful pioneer lawyer in [[Iowa]] and was one of the town fathers of [[Keokuk, Iowa]]. Johnson was born in [[Pomfret, Vermont|Pomfret]], [[Windsor County, Vermont]], to [[John Johnson (Latter Day Saints)|John Johnson]], and Alice Elsa Johnson. The family moved to [[Hiram, Ohio]], in 1818, where they established the [[John Johnson Farm]], a successful {{convert|300|acre|km2|sing=on}} farm. Johnson died in 1859, drowning in the [[Mississippi River]] in a boating accident at [[Prairie du Chien]], [[Wisconsin]]. He had at least five children. ==Involvement in the Latter Day Saint movement== ===Early contact=== [[Joseph Smith]] and [[Emma Hale Smith]] moved into the Johnson home on September 12, 1831. Within a month, Johnson was ordained an [[Elder (Mormonism)|elder]] and then a [[High Priest (Mormonism)|high priest]] of the [[Church of Christ (Latter Day Saints)|Latter Day Saint church]]. In response to a revelation given on January 25, 1832, Johnson joined [[Orson Pratt]] on an evangelizing mission which took them through the northeastern United States. The two were highly successful preachers and brought many converts to [[Mormonism]] on this and other subsequent missions. ===Quorum of the Twelve=== In the summer of 1834, Johnson marched with the [[Zion's Camp]] expedition which hoped to restore Latter Day Saints in [[Missouri]] to their lands in [[Jackson County, Missouri|Jackson County]]. Although the expedition was a failure, many of the veterans of the expedition were soon called to high leadership positions in the church. Among these were Johnson and his brother [[Luke S. Johnson|Luke]], who were among the original twelve men called on February 14, 1835, to be "Special Witnesses" or [[Apostle (Latter Day Saints)|apostles]] in a "traveling high council" of the church, later known as the Council or [[Quorum of the Twelve]]. The chief duty of the apostles was to preside over missionary activities. Johnson continued to operate as a successful missionary from 1835 to 1837. On September 4, 1834, Johnson was married to Sarah Susan Long. ===Bank failure=== The failure of the [[Kirtland Safety Society]], a bank founded by church leaders, led to widespread dissent in 1837. The church held a [[Presiding high council|high council]] trial on September 3, 1837, which ejected Johnson, his brother Luke, and [[John F. Boynton]] from the Quorum of the Twelve. Boynton explained that his difficulties with the church resulted from "the failure of the bank" which he had understood "was instituted by the will and revelations of God, and he had been told that it would never fail".''Kirtland Council Minute Book,'' pp. 184–86. Despite these difficulties, Johnson and the others temporarily reconciled with church leaders and were restored to their apostleships on September 10, 1837,''KCMB'', pp. 188–89 after which Johnson and his family moved to the Latter Day Saint settlement of [[Far West, Missouri]]. ===Excommunications=== Meanwhile, schismatic strife between the loyalist faction and the dissenting faction continued to divide the church in Kirtland. The schismatic strife followed them, but in Far West, the loyalists were able to keep control by excommunicating the leadership of the Missouri church—[[David Whitmer]], [[John Whitmer]], [[W. W. Phelps (Mormon)|W. W. Phelps]]—along with [[Oliver Cowdery]], Johnson, and others. In Johnson's case, a list of seven charges were presented to him by the Far West High Council on April 9, 1838, which included the charge of "saying he would appeal the suit between him & Brother Phineas Young and take it out of the County." Johnson replied on April 12 that "I should not condescend to put my constitutional rights at issue upon so disrespectful a point, as to answer any of those other charges until that is withdrawn & until then shall withdraw myself from your society and fellowship."''Far West Record'', 173–76. ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== {{Wikipedia books |1=Quorum of the Twelve Apostles (LDS Church) }} *William Shepard and H. Michael Marquardt, [http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1052&context=mormonhistory "Lyman E. Johnson: Forgotten Apostle"], ''[[Journal of Mormon History]]'' '''36''':93 (2010). *Fred C. Collier (ed.), ''The Kirtland Council Minute Book,'' Collier's Publishing Co., 2002. {{s-start}} {{s-rel|[[Church of Christ (Latter Day Saints)|Church of the Latter Day Saints]] titles
Later renamed: Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints (1838)}} {{succession box | title= [[Quorum of the Twelve|Quorum of the Twelve Apostles]] | years= February 14, 1835–April 12, 1838 | before= [[John F. Boynton]] | after= [[John E. Page]] }} {{s-end}} {{LDSApostles}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johnson, Lyman E.}} [[Category:1811 births]] [[Category:1859 deaths]] [[Category:American Latter Day Saint missionaries]] [[Category:American Latter Day Saint leaders]] [[Category:Apostles of the Church of Christ (Latter Day Saints)]] [[Category:Converts to Mormonism]] [[Category:Former Latter Day Saints]] [[Category:People excommunicated by the Church of Christ (Latter Day Saints)]] [[Category:People from Pomfret, Vermont]] [[Category:Doctrine and Covenants people]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Deaths by drowning]] [[Category:Boating accident deaths]] [[Category:Religious leaders from Vermont]] [[Category:Latter Day Saint missionaries in the United States]]

{{Multiple issues| {{BLP primary sources|date=August 2016}} {{Tone|date=November 2017}}}} '''Maia Damianovic''' (born in [[England]]), grew up in the [[United States]]. Attended the [[University of Toronto]], Ecole Nationale Superieure des Beaux Arts, Ecole du Louvre and the Sorbonne, [[Paris|Paris, France]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maia-damianovic.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208082349/http://www.maia-damianovic.com/ |archivedate=2015-02-08 |df= }}</ref>
Written numerous art critical texts, magazine articles, exhibition catalogues, artist monograms and art reviews.
Independent curator of a number of large-scale projects: The Invisible Touch, Kunstraum Innsbruck; Days of Hope, Frame Programme 49th Venice Biennale; To Actuality, ARGEKUNST, Bolzano, Italy: Enactments of the Self, steirischer herbst art festival: Reality 10’55", Odense, Kunsthallen Brandts Klaedefabrik, Odense, Denmark; future systems: rare momente, Lentos Museum of Contemporary Art, Linz, Austria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/enactments-of-the-self-a-project-by-maia-damianovic/|title=Enactments of the Self, a project by Maia Damianovic - Announcements - e-flux|website=E-flux.com|accessdate=2 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-flux.com/announcements/to-actuality-curated-by-maia-damianovic/|title=To Actuality, curated by Maia Damianovic - Announcements - e-flux|website=E-flux.com|accessdate=2 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.steirischerherbst.at/2002/Personenf2ba.html?PersonenID=26&EreignisseID=12 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208083050/http://www.steirischerherbst.at/2002/Personenf2ba.html?PersonenID=26&EreignisseID=12 |archivedate=2015-02-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saatchigallery.com/artists/christoph_schmidberger_resources.htm|title=Christoph Schmidberger - Other Resources - The Saatchi Gallery|first=Saatchi|last=Gallery|website=Saatchigallery.com|accessdate=2 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plexus.org/review/damianovic/offend.html|title=PLEXUS / REVIEW: Maia Damianovic - Sorry, we didn't mean to offend|website=Plexus.org|accessdate=2 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.khm.de/~achim/innsbruck.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411055850/http://www.khm.de/~achim/innsbruck.html |archivedate=2008-04-11 |df= }}</ref>
Customarily her projects are presented in public and off-site locations. Specialized in situational and performative interactions, and enactments.
Works as architectural designer for futuresystemsprojects, which she co-founded with [[Andy Robinson (design manager)|Andy Robinson]] in 2007.<ref>[http://www.futuresystemsprojects.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208102904/http://futuresystemsprojects.com/ |date=2015-02-08 }}</ref>
== Radical Busts == March through April 2015, she curated "Radical Busts" - a cultural highlight within the Gender Equality section of the 650th Jubilee of the [[University of Vienna]], which presented 36 busts of significant women from Antiquity through Modernism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://medienportal.univie.ac.at/uniview/uniblicke/detailansicht/artikel/radical-busts-gold-schimmernde-frauengeschichten|title=Radical Busts: Gold schimmernde Frauengeschichten|website=Medienportal.univie.ac.at|accessdate=2 November 2017}}</ref>

{{Infobox baseball biography | name = Mark Lowe | image = Mark Lowe on August 8, 2015.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Lowe with the Toronto Blue Jays | position = [[Relief pitcher]] | team = Free agent | number = | bats = Left | throws = Right | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1983|6|7}} | birth_place = [[Houston, Texas]] | debutleague = MLB | debutdate = July 7 | debutyear = 2006 | debutteam = Seattle Mariners | statleague = MLB | statyear = 2016 season | stat1label = [[Win–loss record (pitching)|Win–loss record]] | stat1value = 10–27 | stat2label = [[Earned run average]] | stat2value = 4.22 | stat3label = [[Strikeout]]s | stat3value = 352 | stat4label = [[Walks plus hits per inning pitched|WHIP]] | stat4value = 1.42 | teams = * [[Seattle Mariners]] ({{mlby|2006}}–{{mlby|2010}}) * [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] ({{mlby|2010}}–{{mlby|2012}}) * [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]] ({{mlby|2013}}) * [[Cleveland Indians]] ({{mlby|2014}}) * [[Seattle Mariners]] ({{mlby|2015}}) * [[Toronto Blue Jays]] ({{mlby|2015}}) * [[Detroit Tigers]] ({{mlby|2016}}) }} '''Mark Christopher Lowe''' (born June 7, 1983) is an American [[professional baseball]] [[relief pitcher]] who is a free agent. He previously played for the [[Seattle Mariners]], [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]], [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]], [[Cleveland Indians]], [[Toronto Blue Jays]], and [[Detroit Tigers]]. His [[fastball]] has been clocked as high as 101 mph. He also throws a [[slider]] and a [[circle changeup]].
==College career== Lowe attended the [[University of Texas at Arlington]]. He also pitched for the [[Wisconsin Woodchucks]] in the 2002 and 2003 summer seasons and was a part of their championship team in 2003.
==Professional career== ===Seattle Mariners=== Lowe was drafted by the [[Seattle Mariners]] in the fifth round of the [[2004 MLB Draft]] and began his career with the [[Everett AquaSox]] of the Class-A [[Northwest League]]. In 22 starts with the [[Wisconsin Timber Rattlers]] in 2005, he made 22 starts and was 6–6 with a 5.47 ERA. He proceeded to play for the [[Inland Empire 66ers of San Bernardino]] and [[San Antonio Missions]] in 2006.
====2006==== He made his Major League debut for the [[Seattle Mariners]] on July 7, 2006 in [[Relief pitcher|relief]] against the [[Detroit Tigers]], loading the bases before [[Strikeout|striking out]] the side. He opened his career by throwing 17-2/3 scoreless innings. He picked up his first win on July 19 against the [[New York Yankees]]. Lowe was placed on the [[disabled list]] on August 20 with right elbow tendinitis and was later transferred to the 60-day disabled list. He underwent [[arthroscopic surgery]] on his elbow after the season.<ref>{{cite press release | title = Update on right-handed pitcher Mark Lowe | publisher = Seattle Mariners | date = September 29, 2006 | url = http://seattle.mariners.mlb.com/NASApp/mlb/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20060929&content_id=1690219&vkey=pr_sea&fext=.jsp&c_id=sea }}</ref>
====2007==== Lowe was placed on 60-Day disabled list on April 1 and began a rehabilitation assignment on July 3 with the Triple-A [[Tacoma Rainiers]]. He also made rehab appearances for the Short Season [[Everett AquaSox]] and the [[West Tenn Diamond Jaxx]] before being activated on July 24, He was 0–0, with a 6.75 ERA in four relief appearances, during his seven rehab appearances in West Tennessee, Everett and Tacoma. He was optioned to Tacoma on August 9 to make room on the roster for [[John Parrish (baseball)|John Parrish]]. He was recalled from Tacoma and placed on 15-day DL on August 28. He was rated by [[Baseball America]] as the Mariners number 8 prospect heading into the 2008 season.
====2008–2009==== [[File:AAAA3646 Mark Lowe.jpg|220px|thumb|Lowe pitching for the [[2008 Seattle Mariners season|Seattle Mariners in 2008]]]] In 2008 Lowe set career-highs in games (57), innings (63.2), and strikeouts (55). Among Mariners relievers, he ranked second in games, third in innings and third in strikeouts. He was 0–2, with a 3.60 ERA at home, the 6th-lowest home ERA by a reliever in the [[American League]]. He began the season by making 12 scoreless relief appearances in his first 13 games. Lowe recorded a 0.55 ERA by allowing just one run in 16.1 innings from March 31 to June 13. He tossed at least 2 innings in 12 of his 57 appearances.
He recorded his first Major League save April 11 against the [[Los Angeles Angels]].<ref>[http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080411&content_id=2517448&vkey=recap&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb# Mariners hope its first of many]''mlb.com''</ref> Lowe was optioned to Tacoma on August 25, but did not make an appearance. He was recalled on September 2.
===Texas Rangers===
====2010==== On July 9, 2010, Lowe was traded to the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] with [[Cliff Lee]] for [[Justin Smoak]] and prospects [[Blake Beavan]], [[Josh Lueke]] and [[Matt Lawson]]. He made his debut for the Rangers on September 29, 2010 against Seattle, coming back from injury to throw a scoreless inning against his former team.<ref>{{cite web|author=T.R. Sullivan / MLB.com |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20100709&content_id=12103300&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb |title=Rangers acquire Lee from Mariners | MLB.com: News |publisher=Mlb.mlb.com |date=June 29, 2010 |accessdate=October 23, 2011}}</ref>
====2011==== Lowe was included on the Rangers postseason roster for 2011 after posting an ERA of 3.80 in 52 games. He was on the mound when [[David Freese]] hit the walk off home run to end Game 6 of the [[2011 World Series]].
====2012==== He appeared in 36 games in 2012, with a 3.43 ERA.
===Los Angeles Angels=== On February 8, 2013, he signed a minor league contract with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] that included an invitation to spring training. The Dodgers released him on March 24 and he signed another minor league contract, this time with the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|Los Angeles Angels]] on March 27.<ref>[http://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2013/03/angels-sign-mark-lowe.html Angels Sign Mark Lowe]</ref> He was designated for assignment on May 29, and released on June 6.
===Washington Nationals=== On June 11, 2013, the [[Washington Nationals]] signed Lowe to a minor league contract and assigned him to the [[Syracuse Chiefs]] of the Triple-A [[International League]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Kolko |first=Dan |url=http://www.masnsports.com/nationals_pastime/2013/06/nats-sign-veteran-righty-mark-lowe-to-minor-league-deal.html |title=Nats sign veteran righty Mark Lowe to minor league deal (with lineups) |work=MASN |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=July 19, 2013}}</ref>
===Tampa Bay Rays=== Lowe signed a minor league deal with the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] on November 20, 2013. He was released on March 26, 2014.
===Cleveland Indians=== Lowe signed a minor league deal with the [[Cleveland Indians]] in April 2014. He was called up to the majors from the Triple-A [[Columbus Clippers]] on May 22. He was designated for assignment on July 8,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/tribe/index.ssf/2014/07/cleveland_indians_place_strugg.html |title=Cleveland Indians place struggling pitcher Justin Masterson on the disabled list |date=July 8, 2014 |accessdate=July 8, 2014 |work=cleve land.com |first=Zack |last=Meisel}}</ref> and assigned outright to Columbus on July 12. Lowe elected free agency on October 12, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2014/10/minor-moves-reimold-wilson-cedeno-bianchi-pagnozzi.html|title=Minor Moves: Reimold, Wilson, Cedeno, Bianchi, Pagnozzi|last=Creech|first=Edward|work=mlbtraderumors.com|date=October 12, 2014|accessdate=October 12, 2014}}</ref>
===Seattle Mariners=== On December 18, 2014, the Seattle Mariners signed Lowe to a minor league contract with an invitation to spring training. Before he was traded, Lowe had pitched 36 innings in 34 appearances out of the bullpen for the Mariners, with an ERA of 1.00.
===Toronto Blue Jays=== On July 31, 2015, Lowe was traded to the Toronto Blue Jays for [[Rob Rasmussen]], Jacob Brentz, and Nick Wells.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://m.bluejays.mlb.com/news/article/140108866|title=Blue Jays boost bullpen, deal for Lowe|last=Chisholm|first=Gregor|work=MLB.com|date=July 31, 2015|accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref> Over the last two months of 2015, Lowe pitched 19 innings of relief for Toronto, compiling a 3.79 ERA. His combined totals for 2015 (with Seattle and Toronto) were: 55 innings, 1–3 record, 13 games finished, and a 1.96 ERA.
===Detroit Tigers=== On December 8, 2015, the [[Detroit Tigers]] signed Lowe to a two-year, $11 million contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.tigers.mlb.com/news/article/158984010/tigers-mark-lowe-agree-to-2-year-deal|title=Tigers strike 2-year deal with reliever Lowe|first=Jason|last=Beck|publisher=MLB.com|date=December 8, 2015|accessdate=December 8, 2015}}</ref> Lowe struggled in his first season with the Tigers, pitching to a 7.11 ERA in {{frac|49|1|3}} innings.
He was released on March 26, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/story/sports/mlb/tigers/2017/03/26/detroit-tigers-roster-cuts/99661956/|title=Mark Lowe released; Joe Jimenez among Detroit Tigers' latest cuts|work=Detroit Free Press|access-date=2017-03-26|language=en}}</ref>
===Seattle Mariners=== On March 30, 2017, Lowe signed with the Mariners on a minor-league deal, his third stint with the franchise.
===Chicago White Sox=== On July 21, 2017, Lowe was traded to the [[Chicago White Sox]], along with fellow veteran pitcher [[Jean Machi]], and assigned to AAA. He was released on August 19, 2017.
===Los Angeles Dodgers=== On January 30, 2018, Lowe signed a minor league contract with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]].<ref>{{citeweb|title=Dodgers’ Mark Lowe: Latches on with Dodgers|url=https://www.cbssports.com/fantasy/baseball/news/dodgers-mark-lowe-latches-on-with-dodgers/|date=January 30, 2018|website=cbssports.com}}</ref> He was released on March 12.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2018/03/dodgers-release-mark-lowe-2.html|last=Adams|first=Steve|title=Dodgers Release Mark Lowe|work=MLB Trade Rumors|date=March 12, 2018|accessdate=March 12, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Lowe played High School Baseball at Fort Bend Baptist Academy in [[Sugar Land, Texas]]. Lowe was diagnosed with [[diabetes]] in 2008. Although initially he was diagnosed as a [[Type 2 diabetes|Type 2 diabetic]], his diagnosis was changed to [[Type 1 diabetes|Type 1]] before the 2009 season.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=4034892 Seattle Mariners Pitchers Deal with Diabetes] ESPN, April 2, 2009</ref>
Mark married Stephanie Morgan on December 4, 2010.<ref>http://graceormonde.com/real-weddings/fever-pitch-stephanie-mark-get-married/</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{peacock|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Menaye Donkor |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1981|3|20}} |birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada |nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] |other_names = Menaye Donkor Muntari |citizenship = [[Canadian nationality law|Canada]] and [[Ghanaian nationality law|Ghana]] |education = [[Marketing]], [[Business marketing]] |alma_mater = [[York University]]
([[Bachelor of Business Administration|BBA]]) |occupation = [[businesswoman]], [[Model (person)|model]], [[entrepreneur]], [[philanthropist]] |known_for = [[Miss Universe]], 2004
[[Miss Universe Ghana]], 2004 |height_cm = 180 |spouse = {{marriage|[[Sulley Muntari]]|2010}} |children = Jamal Krasie Muntari |awards = |website = [http://www.menaye.org/ www.menaye.org] }} '''Menaye Donkor''' (born 20 March 1981) is a Canadian-born Ghanaian businesswoman, entrepreneur, philanthropist, and former beauty queen who was named Miss Universe Ghana 2004,{{cite web | url =http://allafricafashion.com/philanthropist-model-and-former-miss-universe-ghana-menaye-donkor-muntari-announced-as-afwl-2012-ambassador/ | title = Philanthropist, model and former Miss Universe Ghana, Menaye Donkor Muntari announced as AFWL 2012 ambassador | accessdate =30 July 2012 | publisher =allafricafashion.com}} and represented [[Ghana]] in [[Miss Universe 2004]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanasoccernet.com/menaye-donkor-not-your-average-footballer%E2%80%99s-wife/|title=Menaye Donkor: Not Your Average Footballer’s Wife|publisher=Ghanasoccernet.com|accessdate=30 July 2012}} Donkor is the wife of [[Ghana]]ian professional footballer [[Sulley Muntari]].{{cite web|url=http://nicoldenoir.blogspot.com/2012/04/new-african-woman-magazine-with-menaye.html|title=Menaye Donkor: Who's that girl?|publisher=Africasia.com|accessdate=30 July 2012}} ==Early life== Menaye Donkor was brought up by her parents in [[Accra]], Ghana, and is the youngest of seven siblings with four brothers and two sisters. At the age of seven she inherited the job title of "Royal Stool Bearer" for her paternal grandmother, who is the Queen mother of Agona Asafo.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/entertainment/I-m-a-true-African-woman-Menaye-Donkor-235001|title=I’m a true African woman-Menaye Donkor|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 September 2017}} Donkor received her childhood education in [[Ghana]], lived and studied in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], USA, during her high school years, and moved back to her birthplace in [[Toronto]] to study [[marketing]] and [[business marketing]] at [[York University]], where she graduated with honours. In the summer of 2011, she studied film at The Studio (formerly The Sally Johnson Studio) in [[New York City]] and then completed a film course with [[Brian Deacon]] at the London Academy of Film, Media and Television. ==Career== In her early twenties Menaye Donkor won the title [[Miss Universe Ghana]],{{Cite web|url=https://ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/entertainment/Muntari-pushed-me-to-Miss-Universe-Ghana-Menaye-580913|title=Muntari pushed me to Miss Universe Ghana — Menaye|website=ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 September 2017}} and spent a few years travelling the world, working as a model. She appeared on the covers of many magazines in [[Ghana]], [[South Africa]] and [[Italy]] such as ''New African Woman'', ''Pompey Life'', ''SportsWeek (La Gazetta dello sport)'', ''Canoe Magazine'' and ''Maxim Italy''. She represented [[Chopard]] at [[Cannes Film Festival|The Cannes Films Festival]] in 2012 and 2013 respectively. She co-managed and marketed her then boyfriend [[Sulley Muntari]] brand from 2006 until 2009. In 2012, she became the face of [http://www.printexghana.com/ Printex],{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsghana.com.gh/new-face-of-printex-menaye-donkor-tours-printex-outlets/|title=New face of Printex Menaye Donkor tours Printex outlets|date=27 June 2012|work=News Ghana|access-date=29 September 2017|language=en-US}} a fabric and textiles company in Ghana. Menaye was the ambassador of [[Africa Fashion Week London]] in both 2012 and 2013. She also owns and manages a real estate company in Ghana. == SHE-Y by Menaye == Menaye developed and founded the luxury Italian brand SHE-Y. The brand launched its first all-natural products early in 2016 using ethically-sourced [[Shea butter]] from [[Ghana]]. Her brand plays a part in her charity work by creating more job opportunities in Shea Butter production. A percentage of sales profit of SHE-Y is donated towards Menaye Charity Organization to help educate less fortunate children.{{Cite web|url=http://www.menaye.org/charity/|title=Menaye Donkor Official Website|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == Philanthropist == Menaye founded the Menaye Charity Organization in 2004 contributing towards the welfare of underprivileged children through providing free quality education in Ghana. Donkor has worked tirelessly for over a decade to improve the lives of women and children in her home country Ghana through the Menaye Charity Organization. The Organisation provides free quality basic education and scholarships to rural underprivileged children in Ghana, health care and the developmental of young girls. She is solely responsible for raising funds to support the organization.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/diaspora/Menaye-Donkor-shares-her-passion-for-giving-back-519539|title=Menaye Donkor shares her passion for giving back|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 September 2017}} === The Menaye School of Hope === The school was founded on 7 September 2000 in the central region of [[Ghana]]. Menaye Donkor adopted the school in 2004 after winning Miss Universe Ghana to help build a better environment for the children as the original school lacked in basic necessities. The school is located in Agona Asafo, which is considered one of the most deprived regions of the country, with high poverty and extreme illiteracy rates. Having started with 78 pupils sharing one school block, the school now has over 400 children and three blocks, helping students achieve excellent results in their [[BECE]] (pre-secondary school) examinations. The Menaye Charity Organisation funds everything for the school, from the buildings and equipment to the teachers’ salaries, as well as uniforms, books and stationery. == Awards == In September 2012, Menaye was honored and chosen by the Chief and elders, of Agona Asafo in the Central Region of Ghana, to be the ‘Nkosuohemaa’ or ‘Development Queen’ of Agona Asafo.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/entertainment/Sulley-Muntari-s-Wife-Now-Nkosuohemaa-of-Agona-Asafo-250164|title=Ghana Web|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Her official title is Nanahemaa Menaye Afumade Afrakoma I. It signifies her global responsibility to her people and as well as her contributions to society. In 2013 she made the list of the 15 Most Influential Africans in Canada,{{Cite web|url=http://entertainment.myjoyonline.com/pages/news/201302/101455.php|title=Joy Online|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} which celebrated individuals who continuously inspire others through great achievements. In 2015, Menaye was honored with the "Woman of The Year" award by the Infant Charity Award in Milan.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.it/benessere/salute-e-prevenzione/15/03/19/infant-charity-award-2015|title=VanityFair.it|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The Infant Charity Award is an organization that recognizes the work of different individuals and associations who support improving the lives of sick children. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * "[http://www.menaye.com/about/ About : Menaye Donkor is a model/actress, entrepreneur and philanthropist]." www.menaye.com. Retrieved 1 April 2014 * "[http://www.modernghana.com/music/21186/3/menaye-charity-organisation-presents-menaye-school.html Menaye Charity Organisation Presents Menaye School of Hope GALA ...‘Together for Hope]." www.modernghana.com. Retrieved 1 April 2014 * "[http://myafrica.allafrica.com/view/people/main/id/0DlF3CxABNZhTEJF.html Menye Donkor]" Retrieved 1 April 2014 * [http://www.vogue.it/en/vogue-black/spotlight-on/2012/05/menaye-donkor Menaye Donkor] at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' {{Miss Universe 2004 delegates}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Donkor, Menaye}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian people of Ghanaian descent]] [[Category:Financial advisors]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Ghanaian beauty pageant winners]] [[Category:Ghanaian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ghanaian people of Canadian descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Miss Universe 2004 contestants]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:York University alumni]]

'''Michael Kinsley''' (born March 9, 1951) is an [[politics of America|American political]] [[journalist]] and [[Pundit (expert)|commentator]]. Primarily active in print media as both a writer and editor, he also became known to television audiences as a co-host on ''[[Crossfire (U.S. TV program)|Crossfire]]''. Kinsley has been a notable participant in the mainstream media's development of online content.
== Early life and education == Kinsley was born to a [[American Jewish|Jewish]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/culture/article/what_will_new_republic_exodus_mean_for_american_jewish_thought|work=Jewish Journal|title=What Will 'New Republic' Exodus Mean for American Jewish Thought?|last=Weiss|first=Anthony|date=December 9, 2014}}</ref> family in [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]], the son of Lillian (Margolis) and George Kinsley, who practiced medicine.<ref>https://www.vanityfair.com/news/1994/11/nancy-collins-on-michael-kinsley</ref><ref>https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/washingtonpost/obituary.aspx?n=lillian-kinsley&pid=137105663</ref> He attended the [[Cranbrook Kingswood School|Cranbrook School]] in [[Bloomfield Hills, Michigan]], then graduated from [[Harvard College]] in 1972. At Harvard, Kinsley served as vice president of the university's daily newspaper, ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''. He was awarded a [[Rhodes Scholarship]] and studied at [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]], [[Oxford University|Oxford]], then returned to Harvard for law school.
== Early career == While still a third-year law student, Kinsley began working at ''[[The New Republic]]''. He was allowed to finish his Harvard [[juris doctor]] degree through courses at the evening program at [[The George Washington University Law School]].
Kinsley's first exposure to a national television audience was as moderator of [[William F. Buckley, Jr.|William Buckley's]] ''[[Firing Line (TV series)|Firing Line]].'' In 1979, he became editor of ''The New Republic'' and wrote the magazine's [[TRB (writer)|TRB]] column for most of the 1980s and 1990s. That column was reprinted in a variety of newspaper op-ed pages, including the ''[[Washington Post]],'' and made Kinsley's reputation as a leading political commentator.
Kinsley also served as managing editor of ''[[Washington Monthly]]'' (in the mid-1970s, while still in school), editor at ''[[Harper's]]'' (for a year and a half in the early 1980s), and American editor of ''[[The Economist]]'' (a short-term, honorary position).
==''Crossfire'' and ''Slate''== From 1989 to 1995, Kinsley appeared on [[CNN]]'s ''[[Crossfire (U.S. TV program)|Crossfire]]'', co-hosting with conservative [[Pat Buchanan]]. Representing the [[American liberalism|liberal]] position in the televised political debates, Kinsley combined a dry wit with [[nerd]]y demeanor and analytical skills.
In January 1995, Kinsley had a cameo on the first episode of the TV sitcom ''[[Women of the House]]'', in which the show's main character, Suzanne Sugarbaker, was a guest on ''[[Crossfire (U.S. TV program)|Crossfire]]''. He also appeared in three movies during the 1990s: ''[[Rising Sun (film)|Rising Sun]]'' ([[1993 in film|1993]]), ''[[Dave (film)|Dave]]'' (1993), and ''[[The Birdcage]]'' ([[1996 in film|1996]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Michael Kinsley|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0455911/|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref>
After leaving ''Crossfire'' in 1995, Kinsley returned to his editorial roots, relocating to [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]] to become founding editor of [[Microsoft]]'s online journal, ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''. In 1998 he was considered for the position of editor in chief of ''[[The New Yorker]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last=Colford|first=Paul|title=Figures Tell Grim New Yorker Story|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/jul/16/news/ls-4266|accessdate=April 12, 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|date=July 16, 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Shafer|first=Jack|title=I Would Have Loved To Piss on Your Shoes|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/press_box/2011/06/i_would_have_loved_to_piss_on_your_shoes.single.html|accessdate=April 12, 2014|work=Slate|date=June 6, 2011}}</ref> but it was ultimately awarded to [[David Remnick]]. In 1999 he was named Editor of the Year by the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'' for his work at ''Slate''.
Kinsley stepped down from ''Slate'' in 2002, shortly after disclosing that he had [[Parkinson's disease]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/going-public-with-parkinsons|title=Going Public With Parkinson's|author=Staff|date=December 10, 2001|website=CBSNews.com|publisher=CBS Interactive, Inc.|accessdate=January 25, 2015}}</ref>
==Subsequent positions== Kinsley next moved to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' as editorial page editor in April 2004. He maintained his Seattle residence and often worked from there, commuting to Los Angeles on a part-time basis. During his tenure, Kinsley tried to overhaul the paper's editorial page and led an abortive experiment with a [[Wikitorial]], while also receiving criticism from [[University of Southern California|USC]] professor and [[feminist]] [[advocate]] [[Susan Estrich]] alleging a dearth of editorials written by women. Kinsley announced his departure in September 2005 after a falling out with the publisher.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/09/13/AR2005091301668.html|work=The Washington Post|title=Michael Kinsley and the LA Times Part on 'Unfortunate Note'|first=Howard|last=Kurtz|date=September 14, 2005|accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref>
He returned to writing a weekly column for ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', and in 2006 he served briefly as American editor of ''[[The Guardian]]''. He also became a regular columnist for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, but in May 2009 wrote that the magazine had "dumped" him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/politics/backward-runs-newsweek |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ney7ndsA?url=http://www.tnr.com/article/politics/backward-runs-newsweek |archivedate=February 19, 2010 |last=Kinsley |first=Michael |title=Backward Runs 'Newsweek' |work=The New Republic |date=May 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On September 9, 2010, Kinsley and [[MSNBC]] pundit [[Joe Scarborough]] joined the staff of ''[[Politico]]'' as the publication's first opinion columnists. On April 29, 2011, [[Bloomberg L.P.]] announced that Kinsley had joined the Bloomberg View editorial board. In January 2013, Kinsley re-joined ''[[The New Republic]]'' as editor at large.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/21/michael-kinsley-returns-new-republic-tnr-relaunch_n_2340795.html|first=Michael|last=Calderone|title=Michael Kinsley Returns to The New Republic as Editor-at-Large|work=Huffington Post|date=December 12, 2012}}</ref> In January 2014, ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' announced that Kinsley would become a contributing editor and write a monthly column.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2014/01/michael-kinsley-columnist-vanity-fair|title=Michael Kinsley Named Columnist for Vanity Fair by Graydon Carter|work=Vanity Fair|date=January 19, 2014|accessdate=February 13, 2014}}</ref>
==Personal== In 2002 Kinsley married [[Patty Stonesifer]], a longtime top executive at [[Microsoft]] and the [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]]. (As a Microsoft vice president, she had managed the Microsoft news portion of the [[MSNBC]] merger, which included ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''.) Stonesifer has two adult children from a previous marriage. She is currently president and CEO of [[Martha's Table]], a non-profit that develops sustainable solutions to poverty.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leadership|url=http://marthastable.org/about/leadership-marthas-table/|publisher=Martha's Table|accessdate=April 30, 2016}}</ref>
In 2002 Kinsley revealed that he had [[Parkinson's disease]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1828325,00.html|work=Time|title=The Audacity of Bill Gates|date=July 31, 2008|accessdate=May 12, 2010|first=Michael|last=Kinsley}}</ref> and on July 12, 2006, he underwent [[deep brain stimulation]], a type of surgery designed to reduce its symptoms. According to a humorous postscript to his ''Time'' column anticipating the surgery, the operation went well; Kinsley's first words out of the operating room were "Well, of course, when you cut taxes, government revenues go up. Why couldn't I see that before?"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1214919,00.html|work=Time|title=Yes, It Really Is Brain Surgery|date=July 16, 2006|accessdate=May 12, 2010|first=Michael|last=Kinsley}}</ref>

{{spanish name|Rubio|Fernández}} {{Infobox person | name = Pilar Rubio | image = Pilar Rubio.jpg | caption = Pilar Rubio during the Festival de Cine Fantastico de Catalunya in 2009 | birthname = Pilar Rubio Fernández | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|3|17|40}} | birth_place = [[Torrejón de Ardoz]], [[Community of Madrid]], [[Spain]] | othername = Pili | yearsactive = 1990–present | partner = [[Sergio Ramos]] (2012–present) | children = {{collapsible list|title=3|Sergio Ramos Rubio (2014)|Marco Ramos Rubio (2015)|Alejandro Ramos Rubio (2018)}} | website = {{URL|pilarrubio.com}} | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | occupation = Presenter, actress and model }}
'''Pilar Rubio Fernández''' (born 17 March 1978) is a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[reporter]] and [[Television|TV]] [[Television presenter|presenter]]. She became famous for covering events for the program ''[[Sé lo que hicisteis...]]'' for the television network [[La Sexta]]. From January 2010 to January 2013 she was linked to [[Telecinco]], having hosted ''[[Operación Triunfo (Spain)|Operación Triunfo]]'' and ''[[¡Más que baile!]]'', besides of being the protagonist of the series ''[[Piratas]]'', released in May 2011. Since 2014 she appears as collaborator in ''[[El Hormiguero]]''. In 2012, she started a relationship with footballer [[Sergio Ramos]], with whom she has three children.
==Trajectory==
She began to study Economics, although she did not finish the degree.<ref>{{cite news |language=es |url=http://www.lasprovincias.es/castellon/20080728/vida-ocio/agradezco-consideren-sexy-20080728.html |title="Agradezco que me consideren sexy" |newspaper=[[Las Provincias]] |first=Mercedes |last=Rodríguez |date=28 July 2008 |access-date=24 September 2018 |location=Madrid |publisher=[[Vocento]]}}</ref> She modelled in several men's magazines, and appeared in the movies ''[[Isi & Disi, alto voltaje]]'' and ''[[Carlitos y el campo de los sueños]]'', also in two shorts: ''Merry Christmas'' of Fran Casanova and ''Cuestión de química'' of Juan Moya, acting along with [[Cristina Peña]] and [[Arturo Valls]] among others. In television she has appeared in commercials [[Amstel Brewery|Amstel]], [[Canal+ Spain|Canal+]], [[Hyundai Motor Company|Hyundai]] and in programs like ''Lo que necesitas es amor'', ''[[The Price Is Right]]'', ''La azotea de Wyoming'' and in ''Six pack'', broadcast by the network [[Cuatro (TV channel)|Cuatro]]. Her definitive success with the public was her appearance in the comedy program ''Sé lo que hicisteis...'' of La Sexta, in which she looked at diverse news articles. In the summer of 2007 in addition she appeared in humorous homemade videotapes program called ''La ventana indiscreta''.
She won the award of best television reporter with Premio Joven 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vanitatis.elconfidencial.com/noticias/2008-07-16/premios-a-gogo-para-pilar-rubio_558839/ |title=Premios a gogó para Pilar Rubio |date=16 July 2008 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[El Confidencial]] |publisher=Titania Compañía Editorial, [[Sociedad Limitada|S.L.]] |language=es}}</ref> In 2008 and 2009 she was selected as the sexiest woman in the world by the Spanish edition of the [[FHM]] magazine.<ref name="Pilar Rubio in FHM Spain magazine">{{cite web |last=Cheresson |first=Lisette |title=Pilar Rubio: 5 Fast Facts You Need To Know |url=http://heavy.com/news/2014/06/pilar-rubio-wag-sergio-ramos-television-presenter/ |work=[[Heavy.com]] |access-date=13 December 2015 |date=17 April 2015 |publisher=[[WordPress]] |language=es}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |language=es |url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/372261/0/pilar/rubio/sexy/ |title=Pilar Rubio es la mujer más sexy del mundo según FHM |newspaper=[[20 minutos]] |access-date=May 15, 2008 |date=23 April 2008 |author=Korpa Television}}</ref>
From 14 July to 29 August 2008, and in July 2009, she presented the program ''Sé lo que hicisteis...'' replacing [[Patricia Conde]], who was on vacation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2009/07/27/television/1248715956.html |title=Pilar Rubio: 'En la televisión soy infiel y promiscua. Me gustan todos' |date=27 July 2009 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]] |language=es |publisher=[[Unidad Editorial]] Internet, [[Sociedad Limitada|S.L.]] |location=Madrid}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.diariosur.es/20080728/gente/pilar-rubio-agradezco-consideren-20080728.html |title=Pilar Rubio: «Agradezco que me consideren sexy, a nadie le amarga un dulce» |first=M. |last=Rodríguez |date=28 July 2008 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[Diario Sur]] |publisher=[[Vocento]] |language=es}}</ref> In January 2010 she was replaced by [[Cristina Pedroche]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2010/01/08/actualidad/1262936938_850215.html |title=Cristina Pedroche, sustituta de Pilar Rubio en 'Sé lo que hicisteis' |author=EFE |author-link=EFE |date=8 January 2010 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[El País]] |language=es |publisher=[[Prisa]] |location=Madrid}}</ref>
She was hired by [[Telecinco]] on 12 November 2009<ref>{{cite web |language=es |url=http://www.telecinco.es/detail/detail17848.shtml |title=Archived copy |access-date=12 November 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091115064339/http://www.telecinco.es/detail/detail17848.shtml |archive-date=15 November 2009 |date=12 November 2009 |work=[[Telecinco]]}}</ref> where she presented ''[[¡Más que baile!]]'' and in 2011 the talent show ''[[Operación Triunfo (Spain)|Operación Triunfo]]'' that was canceled after 35 days due to low ratings.<ref>{{cite journal |language=es |url=http://www.hola.com/noticias-de-actualidad/15-12-2010/78971/ |title=Sara Carbonero será la encargada de dar las campanadas en Telecinco |date=15 October 2010 |access-date=24 September 2018 |magazine=[[Hola!]]}}</ref> In May 2011 she became one of the stars of the new series of Telecinco ''[[Piratas]]''. After 8 episodes, the series had to be withdrawn due to low ratings.
On 13 February 2012 the magazine ''Interviú'' published some of her naked photos taken 14 years before for other publications of the same publishing group.
On 25 June 2012 she presented with José Corbacho the talent contest ''Todo el mundo es bueno'',<ref>{{cite news |language=es |url=http://www.abc.es/20120624/tv/abci-pilar-rubio-corbacho-todo-201206241037.html |title=Pilar Rubio y José Corbacho estrenan su nuevo show: «Todo el mundo es bueno» |newspaper=[[ABC.es]] |first=Daniel |last=Toledo |date=24 June 2012 |access-date=24 September 2018}}</ref> canceled three weeks later due to low ratings.
Since 2014 she appears as a collaborator in the comedy show ''[[El Hormiguero]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.formulatv.com/noticias/35055/el-hormiguero-ficha-pilar-rubio/ |title='El Hormiguero' ficha a Pilar Rubio |work=Formula TV |date=7 January 2014 |access-date=24 September 2018 |language=es |publisher=Noxvo}}</ref>
==Personal life== She began a relationship with the Spanish [[Real Madrid C.F.]] football player [[Sergio Ramos]] in September 2012. It was confirmed during the [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] gala.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.es/estilo/gente/20130108/abci-irina-shayk-pilar-rubio-201301080854.html |title=Pilar Rubio y Sergio Ramos hacen oficial su relación en la gala del Balón de Oro |date=9 January 2013 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[ABC (Spain)|ABC]] |language=es}}</ref> On 12 November 2013 they announced they were waiting a child,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.antena3.com/celebrities/hijos-famosos/pilar-rubio-sergio-ramos-esperan-primer-hijo_2013111200837.html |title=Pilar Rubio y Sergio Ramos esperan su primer hijo |location=Madrid |date=12 November 2013 |access-date=8 October 2018 |work=[[Antena 3 (Spain)|Antena 3]] |publisher=[[Atresmedia Corporación de Medios de Comunicación]], [[Sociedad Anónima|S.A]] |language=es}}</ref> and on 6 May 2014 she gave birth to Sergio.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vanitatis.elconfidencial.com/noticias/2014-05-06/pilar-rubio-y-sergio-ramos-ya-son-padres-de-un-nino-que-se-llama-como-el-futbolista_126350/ |title=Pilar Rubio y Sergio Ramos ya son padres de un niño que se llama como el futbolista |first=Álex |last=Parrado |date=6 May 2014 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[El Confidencial]] |language=es |publisher=Titania Compañía Editorail, [[Sociedad Limitada|S.L.]]}}</ref> On 14 May 2015 she announced she was pregnant,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zeleb.es/n/pilar-rubio-y-sergio-ramos-esperan-su-segundo-hijo-017628 |title=Pilar Rubio y Sergio Ramos esperan su segundo hijo |date=4 May 2015 |access-date=8 October 2018 |work=Zeleb |language=es}}</ref> and on 14 November she gave birth to Marco.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.hola.com/actualidad/2015111581744/pilar-rubio-nace-segundo-hijo/ |title=Nace el segundo hijo de Pilar Rubio y Sergio Ramos, un niño llamado Marco |date=15 November 2015 |access-date=8 October 2018 |magazine=[[Hola!]] |language=es}}</ref> On 5 October 2017 they announced they were waiting a third child,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://as.com/tikitakas/2017/10/04/portada/1507105616_845763.html |title=Sergio Ramos y Pilar Rubio esperan su tercer hijo |first=Laura |last=Eguiluz |date=4 October 2017 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[Diario AS]] |language=es}}</ref> and on 25 March 2018 she gave birth to Alejandro.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/03/26/gente/1522017963_359755.html |title=Nace el tercer hijo de Sergio Ramos y Pilar Rubio |location=Madrid |date=26 March 2018 |access-date=8 October 2018 |newspaper=[[El País]] |language=es |publisher=[[Prisa]]}}</ref>

{{distinguish|Rob Bishop (baseball)}} {{Multiple issues| {{More citations needed|date=February 2017}} {{Inadequate lead|date=February 2017}}}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Rob Bishop |image = Rob Bishop official portrait.jpg |office = Chair of the [[United States House Committee on Natural Resources|House Natural Resources Committee]] |term_start = January 3, 2015 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Doc Hastings]] |successor = [[Raúl Grijalva]] (Designate) |state1 = [[Utah]] |district1 = {{ushr|UT|1|1st}} |term_start1 = January 3, 2003 |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = [[James V. Hansen]] |successor1 = |state_house2 = Utah |district2 = 2nd |term_start2 = 1982 |term_end2 = 1994 |predecessor2 = Stephen Holbrook |successor2 = [[Peter C. Knudson]] |state_house3 = Utah |district3 = 61st |term_start3 = 1978 |term_end3 = 1982 |predecessor3 = Willis Hansen |successor3 = Richard Ellertson |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|7|13}} |birth_place = [[Kaysville, Utah|Kaysville]], [[Utah]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = Jeralynn Hansen |children = 5 |education = [[University of Utah]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) |website = {{url|robbishop.house.gov/|House website}} }} '''Robert William Bishop''' (born July 13, 1951) is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|UT|1}}, and Chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Natural Resources|House Natural Resources Committee]] serving since 2003. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].
==Early life, education, and early career== Bishop was born in [[Kaysville, Utah|Kaysville]], [[Utah]] and graduated from [http://www.davis.k12.ut.us/Domain/7528 Davis High School]. He served as a [[Mormon missionary]] in [[Germany]] from 1970 until 1972. Bishop received a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[political science]] from the [[University of Utah]] in [[Salt Lake City]] in 1974. He taught civics classes at [[Brigham City, Utah|Brigham City]]'s [[Box Elder High School]] from 1974 to 1980; he next taught [[German language|German]] in [[Ogden, Utah|Ogden]], Utah at [[Ben Lomond High School]]; then he returned to teaching [[government]] and [[history]] classes at Box Elder High School until his retirement from teaching in 2002.<ref name=RobBishopBio>{{cite web|title=Rob Bishop Congressional Bio|url=http://robbishop.house.gov/Biography/|archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20070530204600/http://robbishop.house.gov/Biography/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-05-30}}</ref> While a teacher at Box Elder, Bishop partnered with the [[Close Up Foundation]] to help students participate in Close Up's [[Washington, D.C.]] based civic education programs. He remains actively involved in the program and works to ensure that Utah students have the opportunity to visit Washington, D.C.
==Early political career== Bishop was a member of the [[Utah House of Representatives]] from 1978 to 1994. He was House Majority Leader and later served as Speaker of the House from 1992 until 1994. After his retirement from the state legislature, Bishop returned to Box Elder High School and taught [[Advanced Placement|advanced placement]] courses while chairing the history department.
In 1997 he was elected chairman of the [[Utah Republican Party]], and served for two terms in this position. He has also worked as a legislative lobbyist in Washington.
==U.S. House of Representatives==
===Elections=== In 2002, Bishop returned to politics when he ran for the Republican nomination in the 1st District. 22-year incumbent [[James V. Hansen|Jim Hansen]] had recently announced his retirement. At the state Republican convention, he finished first in the seven-candidate field and went on to face State Representative [[Kevin Garn]] in a primary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=217675|title=Our Campaigns - UT District 1 - R Convention Race|accessdate=7 February 2017}}</ref> He defeated Garn in that primary with 59.8 percent of the vote, all but assuring him of being the next congressman from this heavily Republican district.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Campaigns - UT District 1 - R Primary Race|url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=27465|accessdate=7 February 2017}}</ref> As expected, he won the general election with 61% of the vote. He has won re-election in 2004, 2006, 2008, 2010, and 2012 with even larger margins. In 2014, he was reelected with 64% of the vote.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fahys|first1=Judy|title=Replican Bishop Returns to Congress in 1st District|url=http://kuer.org/post/republican-bishop-returns-congress-1st-district|accessdate=20 November 2014|agency=KUER 90.1|publisher=NPR|date=5 November 2014}}</ref>
===Tenure=== As a teacher, he has made education related issues a top priority. He is a strong advocate for increased local control of schools. He opposes [[No Child Left Behind]] and supports [[school vouchers]]. He was also a co-sponsor of a proposed amendment to guarantee a balanced federal budget.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
In 2016 Bishop led drafting efforts on legislation to address the [[Puerto Rican government-debt crisis]].<ref>{{cite news |title=A New Libor Trial and Fed Leaders Onstage |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=February 6, 2017 |date=April 4, 2016 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/04/business/a-new-libor-trial-trade-data-and-fed-leaders-onstage.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Calmes |first=Jackie |title=Treasury Chief Puts a Face on Puerto Rico's Debt Crisis |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 10, 2016 |accessdate=February 6, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/10/business/dealbook/treasury-secretary-jacob-lew-puts-a-face-on-puerto-rico-debt-crisis.html}}</ref>
In the 2016 election cycle, 92.6% of contributions to Bishop's political campaign came from outside Utah, the highest out-of-state percentage of any member of the House, with much of the contributions coming from the energy and agribusiness sectors, according to an analysis by the [[Center for Responsive Politics]].<ref name=npr20170205/><ref>{{cite news |title=For campaign cash, many lawmakers use a big map; Rob Bishop nears 93 percent out-of-state |first=Emma |last=Baccellieri |date=July 8, 2016 |publisher=[[Center for Responsive Politics]] |accessdate=February 5, 2017 |url=https://www.opensecrets.org/news/2016/07/for-campaign-cash-many-lawmakers-use-a-big-map-rob-bishop-tops-the-out-of-state-list/}}</ref>
==== Federalism ====
In 2010 Bishop introduced to the House an amendment to the [[United States Constitution]], known as the "repeal amendment," which would allow a majority vote of the states to overturn any act of the [[United States Congress]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Zernike |first=Kate |authorlink=Kate Zernike |title=Proposed Amendment would Enable States to Repeal Federal Law |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 20, 2010 |accessdate=February 6, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/20/us/politics/20states.html}}</ref>
==== Land use and the environment ====
Bishop supports repeal of the [[Endangered Species Act of 1973]], saying it has been "hijacked" to control land and block economic development, and that he "would love to invalidate" the law.<ref>{{cite news |title=GOP Wants to Change Endangered Species Act |date=January 17, 2017 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/2017/0118/Endangered-Species-Act-get-ready-for-big-changes-says-GOP |accessdate=February 5, 2017 |first1=Matthew |first2=Matthew |last1=Brown |last2=Daly }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/c4809b5e9f4641ffa45e09b390030293|title=GOP targets landmark Endangered Species Act for big changes|work=The Big Story|access-date=2017-03-11|language=en-US}}</ref> Bishop is among those most critical of the [[Antiquities Act]].<ref name=npr20170205>{{cite news |title=Utah Representative Wants Bears Ears Gone And He Wants Trump To Do It |date=February 5, 2017 |first=Kirk |last=Siegler |authorlink=Kirk Siegler |accessdate=February 5, 2017 |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/02/05/513492389/utah-representative-wants-bears-ears-gone-and-he-wants-trump-to-do-it |publisher=[[NPR]] |work=[[Weekend Edition]]}}</ref> Bishop opposed the designation of the [[Bears Ears National Monument]] and supports repealing or shrinking the designation.<ref name=npr20170205/><ref>{{cite news |last=Davenport |first=Coral |title=Obama Designates Monuments in Nevada and Utah |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 29, 2016 |accessdate=February 5, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/28/us/politics/obama-national-monument-bears-ears-utah-gold-butte.html}}</ref> Bishop supports transferring federal public lands to the states.<ref>{{cite news |title=Congress moves to give away national lands, discounting billions in revenue |first=Heather |last=Hansman |date=January 19, 2017 |accessdate=February 5, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jan/19/bureau-land-management-federal-lease}}</ref>
In February 2011, Bishop introduced a budget amendment<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robbishop.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=225394|title=Bishop Introduces Amendment to Defund National Landscape Conservation System|date=16 February 2011|accessdate=5 July 2011}}{{Self-published source|date=February 2017}}</ref> that would have defunded the [[National Landscape Conservation System]], which manages 27 million acres of [[Bureau of Land Management]] land, including the [[U.S. National Monument|National Monument]], [[National Conservation Area]], [[National Wilderness Preservation System|National Wilderness Preservation]], [[National Wild and Scenic Rivers]], [[National Scenic Trail]], [[National Historic Trail]] systems and other systems. After coming under fire for introducing this amendment,<ref>{{cite news |title=Groups blast Bishop over 'gutting' landscape conservation |first=Amy Joi |last=O'Donoghue |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705366847/Groups-blast-Bishop-over-gutting-landscape-conservation.html |accessdate=July 5, 2011 |date=February 16, 2011 |newspaper=[[Deseret News]]}}</ref> Bishop withdrew it.
On April 10, 2013, Bishop introduced the [[Ensuring Public Involvement in the Creation of National Monuments Act]]. The bill would amend the [[Antiquities Act of 1906]] to subject [[National Monument (United States)|national monument]] declarations by the President to the [[National Environmental Policy Act of 1969]] (NEPA).<ref name="1459sum">{{cite web|title=H.R. 1459 – Summary|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/1459|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> At present, the [[President of the United States]] can unilaterally designate areas of federally-owned land as a national monument, whereas national parks and other areas are required to be enacted into law by the [[United States Congress]].<ref name="IBTjohanson">{{cite news|last=Johanson|first=Mark|title=GOP Bill Could Mean 'No More National Parks,' Public Land Advocates Warn|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/gop-bill-could-mean-no-more-national-parks-public-land-advocates-warn-1563152|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=International Business Times|date=24 March 2014}}</ref> Bishop argued that "the American people deserve the opportunity to participate in land-use decisions regardless of whether they are made in Congress or by the President". He claims his new bill would ensure "that new national monuments are created openly with consideration of public input".<ref name="IBTjohanson" />

{{Infobox person | name = Robert John Angers, Jr. | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1919|10|20}} | birth_place = [[Abbeville, Louisiana|Abbeville]], [[Vermilion Parish]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States|USA]] | death_date ={{death date and age|1988|10|13|1919|10|20}} | death_place = [[Houston, Texas|Houston]], [[Harris County, Texas|Harris County]], [[Texas]] | occupation = [[Journalist]]; [[Businessman]] | residence = [[Lafayette, Louisiana|Lafayette]], [[Lafayette Parish]], Louisiana |spouse=Geraldine Isabelle Beaulieu Angers (married, 1941-1988, his death)|children=Robert Gerald, Judith Ann, Trent Michael, Stephen Brion, Winston Thomas, John Matthew, Glen Williams, and Jefferson Mark "Jeff" Angers |parents=Robert Junius Angers and Anna Mae Nunez Angers |party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], 1940-1960; [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], 1960-1974; [[Independent (politics)|Independent]], 1974-1988 |footnotes=(1) Angers's ''[[Acadiana Profile]]'' is the longest-running, still active independent [[magazine]] in Louisiana history.
(2) In 1977. Angers helped to launch the [[interest group]], the International Relations Association of Acadiana to promote goodwill, trade, and tourism with [[French (language)|French]] and [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]]-speaking countries.
(3) [[Rotary International]] established a [[Paul P. Harris|Paul Harris Fellowship]] named in Angers's honor because of his work in the creation of a Rotary Academy of International Studies.
(4) Angers's [[conservative (politics)|conservative]] writings prompted [[Freedoms Foundation]] of [[Valley Forge, Pennsylvania|Valley Forge]] to present Angers with its [[George Washington]] Award.
(5) Though Angers made his only political race as a Louisiana [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], he left the [[Republican Party (United States)|GOP]] after fourteen years and spent the remainder of his life as a registered [[Independent (politics)|Independent]]. }} '''Robert John Angers, Jr.''' (October 20, 1919 – October 13, 1988),<ref name=ssdi>{{cite web|url=http://ssdi.rootsweb.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/ssdi.cgi|title=Social Security Death Index|publisher=Rootsweb.ancestry.com|accessdate=January 28, 2009}}</ref> was an American [[journalist]], [[businessman]], and [[Conservative (politics)|conservative]] [[politician]]. ''A Dictionary of Louisiana Biography'' describes Angers as "a tireless and unselfish promoter of good government, the [[Acadiana]] region, and [[free enterprise]]."<ref name=dlb>Robert John Angers, ''A Dictionary of Louisiana Biography'', Lafayette: Louisiana Historical Association, 1999, pp. 4-5</ref>
==Early years, education, military==
Angers was born in [[Abbeville, Louisiana|Abbeville]], the seat of [[Vermilion Parish]], to Robert J. Angers (1894–1965)<ref name=ssdi/> and the former Anna Mae Nunez (1898–1988).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gsr&GSln=Angers&|title=Anna Mae Nunez Angers|publisher=findagrave.com|accessdate=January 29, 2009}}</ref> He graduated from [[Catholic High School (New Iberia, Louisiana)|Catholic High School]], then known as St. Peter's College of [[New Iberia, Louisiana|New Iberia]]. In 1940, he procured his [[Bachelor of Arts]] in journalism from [[Louisiana State University]] in [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]]. During [[World War II]], Angers was a [[major (rank)|major]] of the [[United States Army]]'s 24th Infantry Regiment. He received the [[Combat Infantryman Badge]] and the [[Bronze Star]]. In 1949, Angers graduated from the [[Command and General Staff College]] in [[Fort Leavenworth, Kansas]].<ref name=dlb/>
==Journalism career==
Angers began his journalism career upon graduation from [[LSU]] with his hometown ''Abbeville Progress''. After wartime service, he became in 1945 the advertising manager in 1945 of the ''Weekly Iberian'' and ''New Iberia Enterprise''. With his father and brother, Allen, Angers co-owned Angers Real Estate Agency in New Iberia from 1946–1950, when he became the [[newspaper publisher|publisher]] of the ''[[Franklin Banner-Tribune]]'' in [[Franklin, Louisiana|Franklin]], the seat of [[St. Mary Parish, Louisiana|St. Mary Parish]]. During his fifteen years at the ''Banner-Tribune'', the newspaper converted from a weekly to a daily publication and won 150 state and national press association awards.<ref name=dlb/>
In 1961, Angers co-founded with future [[Lafayette, Louisiana|Lafayette]] [[Mayor]] [[Kenny Bowen]], Angers, Bowen and Associates public relations firm in Lafayette He sold his interest to Bowen in 1962. From 1966-1968, Angers was an editorial writer and columnist of the ''[[Lafayette Daily Advertiser]]''. He founded the ''Jeanerette Weekly Journal'' (1964–1965), ''Southwest Louisiana Capitalist'' (1963), and ''[[Acadiana Profile]]'' magazine (1968), which covers twenty-two [[South Louisiana]] parishes and is the longest-running still active magazine in Louisiana history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acadianhouse.com/acadianaprofilemagazine/ |title=''Acadiana Profile'': The Magazine of the Cajun Country |publisher=acadianaprofilemagazine |accessdate=January 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011235349/http://www.acadianhouse.com/acadianaprofilemagazine/ |archivedate=October 11, 2008 }}</ref> Assisted by his wife, Angers edited and published ''Acadiana Profile'' from 1968–1985, when his son took over the management.<ref name=lda>"Business Editor Bob Angers dies", ''Lafayette Daily Advertiser'', October 14, 1988, p. 1</ref> His last job in journalism was again at the ''Lafayette Daily Advertiser'' as business editor from 1985 until his death in 1988. From 1967-1968, Angers was also editor of ''Latin American Report'' magazine in [[New Orleans]]. He founded the Acadian News Agency, which [[Print syndication|syndicated]] his public affairs editorials to Louisiana newspapers. Trent Angers acquired the news agency in 1970.<ref name=dlb/>
==Congressional campaign, 1964==
Angers was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] until 1960, when he joined the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. In 1964, he supported [[Charlton Lyons]] for [[governor of Louisiana]]. In July 1964, Angers was a delegate to the [[Republican National Convention]] in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], where he supported [[U.S. Senator]] [[Barry M. Goldwater]] for [[U.S. President]]. He lashed out at the then all Democratic congressional delegation from Louisiana, calling the members "so-called southern conservatives who are really liberals ... that vote with [[Lyndon Johnson]] on nearly all major bills."<ref>''[[Shreveport Journal]]'', July 16, 1964, p. 1</ref>
Angers himself ran as the [[Republican Party (United States)|GOP]] candidate for the Lafayette-based 3rd Congressional District seat against the 16-year [[incumbent]], Democrat [[Edwin E. Willis]] of [[St. Martinville, Louisiana|St. Martinville]]. Angers received 31,806 votes (37.7 percent) to Willis's 52,532 (62.3 percent) and lost every parish in the district. In [[Lafayette Parish]], Angers procured 49.6 percent of the vote and outpolled Goldwater there by 3.5 percentage points. Three other Republicans ran unsuccessfully for U.S. House seats from Louisiana that year: future [[Governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[David C. Treen]] in the New Orleans suburbs, Floyd O. Crawford (1907–1995) of Baton Rouge, and [[William Stewart Walker]] of [[Winnfield, Louisiana|Winnfield]], who opposed the conservative Democrat [[Speedy O. Long]] in the since defunct 8th congressional district.<ref>State of Louisiana, Secretary of State, Election returns, November 3, 1964, U.S. House, Third District</ref> Angers was a Louisiana delegate to the [[1968 Republican National Convention]] which nominated the [[Richard M. Nixon|Nixon]]-[[Spiro T. Agnew|Agnew]] ticket. In 1974, however, Angers left the GOP and re-registered as an [[Independent (politics)|Independent]].<ref name=dlb/>
==Civic activities==
Angers was a member of the St. Pius [[Catholic Church]] of Lafayette. He was also affiliated with a plethora of organizations, including the journalism society, [[Sigma Delta Chi]], the New Iberia Port Commission, the [[Kiwanis]] Club, and [[Rotary International]], which endowed a [[Paul P. Harris|Paul Harris Fellowship]] in his name. He was the founding secretary of the [[trade association]], the Louisiana Intracoastal Seaway Association, and a charter member of the Caribbean-American Freedom League, which worked with Cuban exile groups in unsuccessful efforts to overthrow the [[communist]] government of [[Fidel Castro]]. Angers was a director of the Louisiana [[Sugar Cane]] Festival and the [[Council for the Development of French in Louisiana]]. He was a former president of the Louisiana Press Association, the Franklin Chamber of Commerce (1953), and the Louisiana [[Junior Chamber|Jaycees]] (1949).<ref name=dlb/> He founded and served as the first president of the interest groups, The International Relations Association of Acadiana (TIRAA) and the International Good Neighbor Council. He founded these organizations to promote trade, [[tourism]] and goodwil in [[French (language)|French]] and [[Spanish (language)|Spanish]]-speaking countries.<ref name=lda/> Angers received the [[George Washington]] Honor Medal from [[Freedoms Foundation]] in [[Valley Forge, Pennsylvania|Valley Forge]], [[Pennsylvania]]. Prior to his death, he received the Lafayette Board of Realtors "Good News Award".<ref name=dlb/> He was also cited by the Louisiana Farm Bureau for its "Special Press Award" for his lifetime endeavors of promoting and writing about agriculture.<ref name=lda/>
==Family==
On August 31, 1941, Angers married the former Geraldine Isabelle Beaulieu (born March 3, 1921)<ref>Net Detective, People Search</ref> of [[Jeanerette, Louisiana|Jeanerette]] in [[Iberia Parish]], the daughter of Gerald A. Beaulieu, Sr., and the former Laurice Hebert. The couple had seven sons and a daughter: Robert Gerald, Judith Ann, Trent Michael, Stephen Brion, Winston Thomas, John Matthew, Glen Williams, and Jefferson Mark. Another son died at birth.<ref name=dlb/>
Angers died at [[The University of Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Center]] in [[Houston, Texas|Houston]]. His passing came three months after the death of his mother. He is interred at Lafayette Memorial Park.<ref name=lda/>
